questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You plan to use a multi-region Azure Cosmos DB Core (SQL) API account to store data for a new application suite. The suite contains the applications shown in the following table.

//IMG//


Each application should use the weakest consistency level possible.

Which consistency level should you configure for each application? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Reporting: Bounded staleness (within 5 mins)
Purchasing: Strong (latest committed) 
Fulfillment: Consistent prefix (never out-of-order)

https://willvelida.medium.com/understanding-consistency-levels-in-azure-cosmos-db-77b90dbf3daa

Reporting: Bounded staleness (within 5 mins)
Purchasing: Strong (latest committed)
Fulfillment: Consistent prefix (never out-of-order)

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/use-consistency-models-azure-cosmos-db-sql-api/2-understand

Reporting: Eventual
Purchasing: Strong
Fulfilment: Consistent prefix

Reporting: Eventual
Purchasing: Bounded Staleness
Fulfilment: Strong

Maximum RU/s per physical partition: 10,000 RU/s
Maximum storage per logical partition: 20 GB
It is 20 GB. 50 GB is the maximum size of a physical partition.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You are designing a data model for an Azure Cosmos DB Core (SQL) API account.

What are the partition limits for request units per second (RU/s) and storage? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: BD, these are the queries that have the correct ORDER BY
I think that on top in the grid with data there should be Types and not just Type since in all queries use .types

questions.answer_description:
ARRAY_CONTAINS returns a Boolean indicating whether the array contains the specified value. You can check for a partial or full match of an object by using a boolean expression within the command.
Incorrect Answers:
A: Default sorting ordering is Ascending. Must use Descending order.
C: Order on Orders not on Type.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/sql/sql-query-array-contains

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have an Azure Cosmos DB container named container1.

You need to insert an item into container1. The solution must ensure that the item is deleted automatically after two hours.

How should you complete the item definition? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Answer is ttl and 7200. 
The default time to live is something you set on the container when using the SDK

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a container in an Azure Cosmos DB Core (SQL) API account. The database that has a manual throughput of 30,000 request units per second (RU/s).

The current consumption details are shown in the following chart.

//IMG//


Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that answers each question based on the information presented in the graphic.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Answer 1: 5000 RU/s. You get this by dividing 30000 RU/s by 6 physical partitions. 
Answer 2: 60000 RU/s. The highest RU/s you can scale to without triggering Azure Cosmos DB to split partitions is equal to Current number of physical partitions * 10,000 RU/s. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/scaling-provisioned-throughput-best-practices#step-2-calculate-the-default-maximum-throughput

In an Azure Cosmos DB Core (SQL) API account, each partition supports throughput of up to 10,000 request units per second (RU/s).

The container can scale to a maximum throughput of 30,000 RU/s without requiring a partition split. This is because the maximum RU/s per physical partition in Azure Cosmos DB is 10,000, and since the container is set to a manual throughput of 30,000 RU/s, it can be accommodated within three physical partitions, each handling 10,000 RU/s.

Therefore, each partition supports up to 10,000 RU/s, and the container can scale up to 30,000 RU/s without a partition split.

comments.content: wrong, it can not scale up because it is manually set as 30,000 so if somebody would like to scale it manually to meet the limit then the 60,000 is the correct one.

discussion.content: The correct answer should be 5000 RU/s and 60000 RU/s

comments.content: Correction. it is 10000 RU/s and 60000 RU/s

- Each partition (logical/physical) support upto 10000RU/s
- Graph shows based on partition key id. There are 6 partition key legend. So, The highest RU/s you can scale to without triggering Azure Cosmos DB to split partitions is equal to Current number of physical partitions * 10,000 RU/s. So, 6*10000RU/s = 60000RU/s
ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/scaling-provisioned-throughput-best-practices

discussion.content: How can you know there are 6 physical partitions?

comments.content:
5000 RU/s and 30000 RU/s or 5000 RU/s. and 60000 RU/s.
You give several answers.
Excuse me, I meant 5000 RU/s and 30000 RU/s

The RU for the database is fixed at 30,000, so it cannot exceed 30,000.
The correct answers should be 5,000 RU and 30,000 RU.
